meta.description: Configuration file for MCP server security analysis of React applications

securityRules.title: Prevent XSS Vulnerabilities
securityRules.intent: Ensure dynamic content is properly sanitized and escaped to prevent XSS attacks.
securityRules.recommendation: Avoid using dangerouslySetInnerHTML. Use libraries like DOMPurify or sanitize-html for sanitization. React escapes content by default.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: Scans for usage of known XSS-prone patterns in React components.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to eliminate unsafe patterns and implement proper sanitization.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not catch all XSS vectors, especially in complex codebases or with obfuscated code.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Regularly update dependencies and educate developers on secure coding practices to mitigate XSS risks.

securityRules.title: No Hardcoded Secrets
securityRules.intent: Prevent hardcoded API keys, tokens, and passwords in source code.
securityRules.recommendation: Store all secrets in environment variables. Never commit secrets to version control.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: Scans for common patterns of hardcoded secrets in the code files.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to remove hardcoded secrets and use environment variables.
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May miss secrets that do not match common patterns or are obfuscated.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Implement secret scanning in CI/CD pipelines to prevent future occurrences.

securityRules.title: Check for Vulnerable Dependencies
securityRules.intent: Ensure no known vulnerable packages are installed.
securityRules.recommendation: Regularly run 'npm audit' or 'yarn audit' and update vulnerable dependencies. Use dependabot for automated updates.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: Analyzes package.json for known vulnerable dependencies using npm audit data.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Update or replace vulnerable packages as recommended by audit reports.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-1104: Use of Unmaintained Third Party Components
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not detect vulnerabilities in private or unpublished packages.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Incorporate dependency scanning into regular development workflows.

securityRules.title: Secure API Communication
securityRules.intent: Ensure API calls use HTTPS and proper authentication.
securityRules.recommendation: Always use HTTPS for API calls. Include proper authentication headers and validate SSL certificates.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: Scans for API calls made over insecure HTTP protocols.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to use HTTPS and include necessary authentication.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not catch all insecure API calls, especially in dynamic URL constructions.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Educate developers on the importance of secure communication practices.

securityRules.title: Avoid eval() and Dynamic Code Execution
securityRules.intent: Prevent use of eval() which can execute arbitrary code.
securityRules.recommendation: Never use eval() or Function() constructor. Use safer alternatives like JSON.parse or data-driven approaches.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: Scans for usage of eval() and other dynamic code execution patterns.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to eliminate dynamic code execution and use safer alternatives.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-95: Improper Neutralization of Directives in Dynamically Evaluated Code
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not catch all instances, especially if eval-like behavior is abstracted in custom functions.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Promote secure coding practices to avoid the need for dynamic code execution.

securityRules.title: No Sensitive Data in Console
securityRules.recommendation: Remove logging of passwords, tokens, and other sensitive data in production. Use appropriate log levels.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: Scans for console logging statements that include sensitive keywords.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to remove sensitive data from logging statements.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-117: Improper Output Neutralization for Logs
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not catch all sensitive data logging, especially with obfuscated variable names.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Implement logging policies and educate developers on secure logging practices.

securityRules.title: Don't Store Sensitive Data in localStorage
securityRules.intent: Prevent storing sensitive data like tokens in localStorage (vulnerable to XSS).
securityRules.recommendation: Use secure HTTP-only cookies for sensitive data like authentication tokens. localStorage is vulnerable to XSS attacks.

codeExample.good:
// Use httpOnly cookies set by server
// Server-side: res.cookie('token', authToken, { httpOnly: true })

securityRules.detectionExplanation: Scans for usage of localStorage or sessionStorage to store sensitive data.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to use secure storage mechanisms like HTTP-only cookies.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not catch all instances, especially with obfuscated variable names.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Educate developers on secure storage practices and the risks of client-side storage.

securityRules.title: Validate and Sanitize User Input
securityRules.intent: Ensure all user inputs are validated and sanitized.
securityRules.recommendation: Always validate and sanitize user input on both client and server. Use libraries like Zod or Yup for schema validation.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: Scans for form handlers that do not implement input validation or sanitization.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to include proper validation and sanitization of user inputs.
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not catch all input handling scenarios, especially in complex forms.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Incorporate input validation into development best practices and code reviews.

securityRules.title: Content Security Policy Compliance
securityRules.intent: Ensure code complies with CSP headers.
securityRules.recommendation: Avoid inline event handlers and styles. Use React event handlers and CSS-in-JS or external stylesheets for CSP compliance.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: Scans for inline event handlers and styles that violate CSP policies.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to use React event handlers and external stylesheets.
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not catch all CSP violations, especially with dynamic code generation.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Regularly review CSP policies and educate developers on CSP-compliant coding practices.

securityRules.title: Assess Third-Party Dependencies
securityRules.intent: Evaluate and monitor third-party packages for security risks.
securityRules.recommendation: Review dependencies for security, maintenance status, and popularity. Use tools like Snyk to scan for vulnerabilities.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Review and replace risky dependencies as needed.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-1104: Use of Unmaintained Third Party Components
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not assess the full risk profile of each dependency.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Incorporate third-party risk assessment into regular development workflows.

securityRules.title: Prevent React2Shell Command Injection
securityRules.intent: Detect cases where user-controlled input from React or Next.js flows into shell or OS command execution APIs, leading to command injection vulnerabilities.
securityRules.recommendation: Never pass user-controlled input directly to shell execution APIs. Use allowlists, argument arrays, and proper input validation. Prefer safe libraries like execa with fixed commands.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: This rule uses taint tracking to trace user-controlled input from common React/Next.js sources to shell execution sinks, identifying potential command injection points.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to eliminate direct flow of user input into shell execution functions. Implement strict validation and use safe execution methods.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-78: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an OS Command
securityRules.detectionLimitations: Taint tracking may not cover all complex data flows or obfuscated code patterns.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Educate developers on the risks of command injection and promote secure coding practices.

securityRules.title: Prevent Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
securityRules.intent: Detect potential SSRF vulnerabilities where user input controls server-side HTTP requests.
securityRules.recommendation: Validate and sanitize all user inputs used in server-side requests. Implement allowlists for acceptable domains and URLs.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: This rule uses taint tracking to trace user-controlled input from common React/Next.js sources to server-side HTTP request sinks, identifying potential SSRF points.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to eliminate direct flow of user input into server-side request functions. Implement strict validation and use allowlists for URLs.
securityRules.detectionLimitations: Taint tracking may not cover all complex data flows or obfuscated code patterns.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Educate developers on the risks of SSRF and promote secure coding practices.

securityRules.title: Prevent GraphQL Injection
securityRules.intent: Detect potential GraphQL injection vulnerabilities where user input is directly used in GraphQL queries or mutations.
securityRules.recommendation: Always validate and sanitize user inputs used in GraphQL operations. Use parameterized queries and schema validation libraries.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: This rule uses taint tracking to trace user-controlled input from common React/Next.js sources to GraphQL execution sinks, identifying potential injection points.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to eliminate direct flow of user input into GraphQL operations. Implement strict validation and use parameterized queries.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-943: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements in Data Query Logic ('Injection')
securityRules.detectionLimitations: Taint tracking may not cover all complex data flows or obfuscated code patterns.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Educate developers on the risks of GraphQL injection and promote secure coding practices.

securityRules.title: Prevent SSR XSS Vulnerabilities
securityRules.intent: Detect potential Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities in Server-Side Rendering (SSR) contexts.
securityRules.recommendation: Always sanitize and escape user inputs before rendering them in SSR contexts. Use libraries like DOMPurify for sanitization.
securityRules.detectionExplanation: This rule scans for patterns where user input is directly rendered in SSR responses without sanitization.
securityRules.remediationExplanation: Refactor code to sanitize and escape user inputs before rendering in SSR contexts.
relatedVulnerabilities: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting')
securityRules.detectionLimitations: May not catch all XSS vectors, especially in complex rendering logic.
securityRules.additionalNotes: Regularly update dependencies and educate developers on secure coding practices to mitigate XSS risks.
